awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Efficient Algorithms for Cycles on Surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Many computational problems start with a model that is a mesh or graph drawn on a surface.  A classic example is the representation of a physical object for use in computer graphics systems by selecting points on the surface of the object and approximating the surface with triangles whose corners are the selected points:  the points become the nodes and the sides of the triangles become the edges of a graph and the graph can be viewed as drawn on the surface of the object.  When the surface is simpler, algorithms for manipulating a graph on the surface are more efficient; a surface is more complicated when it has features such as handles and holes.  A common way to deal with these features is to simplify the surface by cutting the surface open to remove the handles and holes.  

This project will develop accurate and efficient methods for simplifying surfaces in this way as well as for other closely related problems.  Because the problems are fundamental, new algorithms for them will provide efficient pre-processing tools for a wide range of applications.  The PIs will involve graduate students in the research and, building on earlier successes and the fostering of a welcoming research environment, endeavor to recruit students from underrepresented populations.

This project will address the above-described "cut-graph" problem as well as the problem of finding the minimum cycle-basis (a minimum-cost way to represent all the cycles in a graph) and the minimum homology-basis (a minimum-cost way to represent all the handles and holes in the surface on which the graph is drawn).  For graphs on surfaces, these problems are very closely related.  By considering these problems together, the PIs will develop fundamental techniques that will be translatable to other problems in these types of graphs.  Cycle bases behave significantly differently in graphs on trivial (handle-free) surfaces than in non-trivial surfaces.  For this reason, by further understanding the properties of surface graphs through the study of these problems, the PIs will provide the next step for algorithm design in surface graphs.

por.por_cntn:
This project studied computational problems for graphs, structures consisting of points connected in pairs by edges, on two-dimensional surfaces. Its particular focus was on splitting graphs into clusters by cutting as few edges as possible, and on finding a cycle basis, a representative set of cycles with the property that all cycles in the graph can be formed as combinations of cycles in this representative set.


Over the course of the project, the PI and his coauthors published approximately 50 peer-reviewed conference and journal papers and one book on topics related to the project. Particularly noteworthy among these many results were the following:


In collaboration with two mechanical engineers, we studied the representative sets of cycles for graphs representing the connectivity between the rigid parts of a moving object. We showed how to find a set whose total cycle length is as small as possible, by an efficient algorithm, and used this construction to develop faster algorithms for analyzing the motion of mechanical linkages.


We observed that real-world road networks are not planar graphs (roads can cross without intersecting) but are well-modeled by a mathematical framework in which the crossings of this type are themselves modeled by a sparse graph. We showed that the road networks described by this framework can be recursively split into clusters using a number of splitting points that, at each level of subdivision, is proportional only to the square root of the size of the network, and developed efficient algorithms for other problems based on this recursive subdivision. We used this subdivision to develop data structures that can maintain a changing set of vehicle locations within this network and quickly find the vehicle nearest any customer. Using this data structure, we devised algorithms for partitioning the overall road network into smaller regions that are compact according to road-network distance and serve equal numbers of customers (see attached image).


In more-theoretical research, we published algorithms for simultaneously solving the minimum cut and cycle basis problem for graphs embedded without crossings in the plane, in near-linear time. We found linear time algorithms for finding a large non-crossing subset of three-vertex separating sets in graph embedded on the plane; this result has important applications to problems of finding non-overlapping pairs of paths in graphs, even when those graphs cannot be drawn without crossings. Additionally, if a graph on a surface is modified by inserting new crossing points whenever two edges cross, we found accurate estimates for the smallest balanced cut in the modified graph, depending on both the size of the graph and the same cut parameter on the original graph.
